Significant zoonotic episodes arise from indirect contact with an animal. Indirect pathogen contamination and dissemination involving reptiles and intermediary surfaces, for example, door handles, clothes, table tops, walls, household utensils and shaking of hands, has been reported as an important factor in transmission.
7, 14, 15 One notable example involved over 300 public attendees to a zoo who acquired Salmonella infection via a wooden stand-off barrier around a lizard enclosure and despite having had no actual contact with the reptiles.
